bug.author: andyljones
bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h2>üêõ Bug</denchmark-h>
When a minimal PyTorch extension is run in cuda-gdb, it crashes with this error: <denchmark-code>cuda-gdb/7.12/gdb/block.c:456: internal-error: set_block_compunit_symtab: Assertion `gb->compunit_symtab == NULL' failed. </denchmark-code>
<denchmark-h:h2>To Reproduce</denchmark-h>
I've put together a minimal Docker container capturing the bug <denchmark-link:https://github.com/andyljones/cuda-gdb-bug>here</denchmark-link> . In particular, see <denchmark-link:https://github.com/andyljones/cuda-gdb-bug/blob/master/run.sh#L7>this command</denchmark-link> , which calls <denchmark-link:https://github.com/andyljones/cuda-gdb-bug/blob/master/bad.cu>this script</denchmark-link> . <denchmark-h:h2>Expected behavior</denchmark-h>
The minimal container also has a contrasting <denchmark-link:https://github.com/andyljones/cuda-gdb-bug/blob/master/good.cu>good.cu</denchmark-link> script which does the same task, but doesn't crash in cuda-gdb. <denchmark-h:h2>Environment</denchmark-h>
Run from inside the container: <denchmark-code>PyTorch version: 1.2.0 Is debug build: No CUDA used to build PyTorch: 10.0.130
OS: Ubuntu 18.04.2 LTS GCC version: (Ubuntu 7.4.0-1ubuntu1~18.04) 7.4.0 CMake version: Could not collect
Python version: 3.7 Is CUDA available: Yes CUDA runtime version: 10.0.130 GPU models and configuration: GPU 0: GeForce RTX 2080 Ti Nvidia driver version: 430.40 cuDNN version: Could not collect
Versions of relevant libraries: [pip] numpy==1.16.4 [pip] torch==1.2.0 [conda] blas 1.0 mkl [conda] mkl 2019.4 243 [conda] mkl_fft 1.0.12 py37ha843d7b_0 [conda] mkl_random 1.0.2 py37hd81dba3_0 [conda] pytorch 1.2.0 py3.7_cuda10.0.130_cudnn7.6.2_0 pytorch </denchmark-code>
<denchmark-h:h2>Additional context</denchmark-h>
I got to this example by starting with a full PyTorch C++ extension <denchmark-link:https://pytorch.org/tutorials/advanced/cpp_extension.html>a la this tutorial</denchmark-link> and pulling bits off until it was easy to read. I can only find <denchmark-link:https://github.com/NVIDIA/cuda-gdb/issues/5>two</denchmark-link> <denchmark-link:https://github.com/daniilidis-group/neural_renderer/issues/65>other</denchmark-link> people reporting this bug, one from 6th June and one from 7th August, so I assume it's due to something recent. <denchmark-link:https://github.com/sakaia>@sakaia</denchmark-link> , <denchmark-link:https://github.com/maphysart>@maphysart</denchmark-link> , if you could provide your specs so I can see if it's just some magic combination of libraries causing it, that'd be a lot of help. The script to generate something like the above is <denchmark-code>wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pytorch/pytorch/master/torch/utils/collect_env.py # For security purposes, please check the contents of collect_env.py before running it. python collect_env.py </denchmark-code>
I tried rolling the minimal example back to PyTorch 1.1, but the shared libs have apparently changed since then and I gave up on trying to get it to build. Going by the line number reported in the bug, cuda-gdb's internals have changed a bit since <denchmark-link:https://github.com/NVIDIA/cuda-gdb>the repo</denchmark-link> was last updated 4yrs ago.

comments.comment: <denchmark-link:https://github.com/andyljones>@andyljones</denchmark-link> Just to check, have you also reported this bug to NVIDIA?
Not so far - was discouraged by how dead the cuda-gdb repo is. Do you know what the best way to report this sort of stuff is?
Thanks. Submitted, bug id is #2676602. Issue report has a link back to this thread.
NVIDIA have fixed this in the 10.1.243 CUDA release.
